title: Master's Thesis - Small-Scale Hydrofoil Boat: Hardware Design
overview: This project focuses on the hardware design and construction of a small-scale radio-controlled hydrofoil boat.
The platform is intended for experimental validation of sensing and control algorithms before deployment on a full-scale solar-powered racing boat.
This work constitutes the hardware-design part of my master's thesis.
highlights: Scaled down the full-sized 'Celka' boat model and CNC-milled the mold for the hull.
Collaboratively sanded and prepared the mold surface with team members.
Laminated the carbon fiber hull inside the mold with a colleague.
Adapted the propulsion system and controller from a different boat (R.O.B.U.R.).
Designed and 3D printed custom parts for mounting the foils and propulsion system.
Struts are reinforcemed with carbon fiber rods for added strength and reduced weight.
Conducted initial water tests to validate the prototype's buoyancy, stability, and basic performance.
CNC machined a composite deck that fits precisely onto the hull for watertight sealing.
Utilized custom jigs for accurate alignment and gluing of front and rear struts to ensure structural integrity.
Assembled electronic hardware in dedicated front and rear compartments, preparing for sensor integration.
results: Successfully constructed a small-scale hydrofoil boat prototype that demonstrates the feasibility of the design for experimental validation.
Achieved precise assembly of all components, including custom 3D printed mounts and CNC machined parts, ensuring structural integrity.
Validated the prototype through water tests, confirming buoyancy and stability for future sensor and control system integration.
Prepared the hardware platform for the next phase of the master's thesis, focusing on sensing and control algorithms.
